# Famine in Travancore during World War II

Famine during World War II was a severe food crisis in the princely state of Travancore (now part of Kerala, India) between 1942 and 1944, peaking in 1943, causing widespread malnutrition and an estimated 90,000 excess deaths.
Background
Travancore’s late 19th and early 20th-century economic transformation into a cash crop economy (tea, rubber, cardamom, coir) increased dependence on rice imports, primarily from Burma. The Japanese conquest of Burma in 1942 cut off Travancore’s main rice supply. Combined with wartime logistic constraints and inter-regional supply competition across British India, this precipitated severe shortages in Travancore.
Economic transformation and import dependence
Cash cropping replaced local subsistence rice cultivation, embedding vulnerability to external conditions through reliance on imported rice via Indian seaports and Burma.
Wartime disruptions after the fall of Burma
The 1942 fall of Burma severed the primary rice source. Competing wartime demands from Ceylon, Cochin, and other deficit regions stressed remaining supplies, leading to price rises and scarcity.
Local substitutes and limitations
Tapioca was promoted as a famine substitute but did not prevent widespread malnutrition and mortality.
Onset and chronology
Early signs in 1942
Administrative and missionary reports cite increasing distress and scarcity following rice import collapse in late 1942.
Peak crisis in 1943
Severe scarcity culminated in famine-like conditions, with widespread hunger, starvation deaths, and disease outbreaks. Estimated excess mortality reached about 90,000.
Continued distress in 1944
Procurement and rationing tightened, but incomplete records and prevailing wartime censorship left many deaths unrecorded.
Causes
Structural dependence and supply shock
The abrupt loss of Burmese rice and redirected demand to Indian mainland producers created acute shortages in Travancore.
Policy and administrative factors
The Diwan of Travancore, C. P. Ramaswami Iyer, implemented a series of reactive measures including permits, stock declarations, and eventually centralized rationing. Implementation was hampered by delays, evasion, and inadequate ration levels.
Market disruptions and employment shocks
Black market activities and collapse of key trades (e.g., coir exports) worsened purchasing power, augmenting food insecurity.
Mortality and health impacts
Severe malnutrition increased vulnerability to diseases such as cholera and smallpox, which contributed to excess deaths. Parish records estimate about 90,000 deaths from 1942 to 1944.
Government response
Travancore’s initial regulatory approach relying on permits and trader self-reporting failed to control prices. Later stages saw centralization of procurement and rationing, but ration quotas remained low and leakages were significant. Neighboring Cochin adopted firmer and timelier procurement policies.
Comparison with Bengal and official inquiries
The Bengal famine of 1943 caused far higher absolute mortality, but Travancore’s proportional losses were significant. The 1945 Famine Inquiry Commission focused mainly on Bengal and lacked sufficient data to classify Travancore’s crisis formally as a famine.
Social and political consequences
Wartime scarcity delegitimized the princely regime and catalyzed leftist political mobilization, contributing to the rise of communism in Kerala. Public memory of the famine remained muted for decades compared to Bengal.
Historiography
Recent research reconstructs mortality and policy responses, challenging narratives minimizing the crisis based on tapioca substitution. Lack of official statistics necessitates reliance on alternative sources.
